caption:
Roughly 200,000 miles of Duke Energy above-ground power lines wind through a six-state footprint that includes the highlands of Kentucky, the mountains of western North Carolina, and the towering willow oaks of Charlotte. In each of these areas, trees and vegetation can pose hazards to power lines and thus, reliability.

Because of the varied terrain Duke Energy covers, the company employs two vegetation teams and a variety of pruning tools and methods to clear trees and vegetation that may interfere with the lines.

“The objective is to maintain the lines – before the trees and brush are close enough to cause outages – in a manner that is consistent with good arboricultural practices,” said Wesley Frick, manager of distribution vegetation at Duke Energy.

Click the link in our bio for more about the team responsible for vegetation management.
